text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have a number of clinical studies uh, that, uh, are in various per deviations of what we could do. Um. So, we || um, have a study of chemotherapy. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Plus vitamin C. That was data that suggest that vitamin C may reduce the side effects from the chemotherapy, may enhance its activity. We don’t know that. That’s a research question. And, so, um then, you are going to go on chemotherapy and are willing to participate, get randomized to get the vitamin C or a dummy infusion. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. That is cumbersome for someone like you. Uh, you’d have to come in at least twice a week to get the vitamin C. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The chemo is every three weeks, but the vitamin C is in high doses and it’s infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, uh, and, as of now, I still think even the placebo equaled yet a dummy infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so, you come in and maybe get tons of sugar. Um. And, we’re trying to sort out side effects of the Docetaxel, and then we can sort of compare it between the two groups --- is, do people have better PSA responses, longer PSA responses or there is no benefit to adding the vitamin C? Patient: Yeah. Okay.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Such as radiation instead of hormone therapy in order to delay you know the need for hormone therapy. And the other is to start the hormone therapy now and try to combine it with something that may make the hormone therapy work better and longer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: From what I’m hearing and reading between the lines, what I think I’m hearing is that you’d rather try at this point in time something that is a non-hormonal approach such as radiotherapy. And if that is the case, I think that we have an interesting study that I could talk to you about which is using what we call stereotactic radiotherapy. It’s also called CyberKnife because the company that makes the machine that delivers the radiation is called CyberKnife. It’s not a knife; it’s a misnomer. It’s not surgery – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But because the beam of radiation is so precise, it’s called a knife because it’s as precise as a surgeon’s knife. Um if you think that I’m misunderstanding and you really are more open to the hormone therapy option as well or instead of radiation and we also have a trial in that category which is trying to ask the question about whether all hormone therapy in conjunction with a new hormone therapy is better than just the old hormone therapy by itself, the conventional. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So I don’t really know where you’re at but I think I’m hearing that you may be interested in thinking about this radiation option first? Patient: Well as a Patient, you have a person that quote/unquote “has the cancer”. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: My primary objective would be to get rid of it. Doctor: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, your January/February scan had maybe something on your adrenal glands, maybe something in your liver, maybe some clumpy lymph nodes, and you’re like oh, okay. So, when I sent you over for like additional, you know, trials you had areas to measure outside your bone but then you kind of don’t. So, on your last CAT scan we couldn’t see anything where the liver was so that’s just not there, the lymph nodes kind of where the adrenal area was is enlarged so you don’t fit that. Oh, that’s wonderful. You made my life a living bleep when I was like oh, yay, but oh, yay, oh, yay, oh. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I’m thrilled that you don’t have the cancer that we say earlier that might have been from the pills you were on Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: but then I’m kind of stuck in terms of well, I’m not really sure if I know where you are right now in October. So, sometimes when I get a little bit stuck and I’m trying to well, there’s this and that, just stop. It doesn’t have to be a mystery because we can just do a full set. So, like you should get a bone scan because the last time was July and we’re in October. You’re in pain so maybe I got to look for new spots that we have to try to treat. That’s one. Then, you know, a bone scan and then a CAT scan, but one that also includes the chest to make sure I’m not missing anything up higher that maybe is causing some of the lower pain. So, I think from here to here and your bone scan we can get that in a few days. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m not gonna fuss. I’m gonna fast forward to say well, whatever that shows I think the question is, you know, what are my options. So, here’s where I’m at. If it’s more than bone, meaning, oh, shoot, maybe that thingy in the liver and the lymph nodes and all that is actually there again and that other one was sort of a fake out then I think you need chemo and I think we’ve been stalling enough for a while that the inevitable is about to happen Mr. H____ you just, you’re gonna, we’re just gonna have to do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: and that’s with docetaxel and Taxotere is the name of the chemo and we do have studies with that so I just, you know, I always want to make sure we talk about that. So, you’d get on Taxotere just alone once every three weeks. It’s an hour infusion. Standard of care anywhere you go in the US. Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then our studies are Taxotere plus high-dose vitamin C versus just the Taxotere. So, two-thirds of the people will get vitamin C. The other one third will just get the chemo. So, everybody gets chemo no matter how I swing this

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
